awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Jennifer S. Brodbelt of the University of Texas at Austin is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry to develop analytical methodologies based on mass spectrometry for the analysis of intact proteins.  These experiments provide information on the locations of multiple posttranslational modifications, which makes it possible to study the influence of those groups on protein function and hence allow better understanding of the structure and properties of biological systems.  The proposed research promises to overcome some of the technical hurdles associated with the activation and dissociation of intact proteins to generate meaningful fragment ion maps that can be used for protein identification.  If successful, the proposed work will positively contribute to the Human Proteome Project, an on-going effort to catalog all human proteins.  It will also facilitate the use of top-down protein mass spectrometry for solving problems in the areas of biotherapeutics,  structural biology, and mechanistic biochemistry.  In this context, the project will provide new avenues for the identification of proteins and hence advance our understanding of life processes.

In this project, studies are being conducted to develop ultraviolet photodissociation (UVPD) as a versatile strategy for the analysis of proteins by mass spectrometry, and to explore the mechanistic, structural, and experimental features that play a role in the ultraviolet photodissociation process.  The project has five separate but related specific aims: (1) to explore the parameters for effective UVPD of intact proteins; (2) to develop a hybrid electron transfer dissociation- ultraviolet photodissociation (ETD/UVPD) methods for mass spectrometric fragmentation of intact proteins; (3) to modify the charge state of proteins for more effective ultraviolet photodissociation; (4) to modulate the selectivity of UVPD by the attachment of specific chromophores to the proteins; and (5) to develop UVPD methodologies for structural biology applications with a focus on determining the structures of intact proteins and the binding interactions of native protein complexes.

During the course of this project, students will be trained in advanced mass spectrometry, laser optics, derivatization reactions, protein processing, and bioinformatics, and summer boot camps will be set up to increase awareness of the potential applications of advanced mass spectrometry for solving biological problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are biological macromolecules that perform numerous roles related to their sequences, structures, and modifications. Even small variations in protein structures can have enormous impact on their chemical properties and how they function in cells and tissues.  The goal of the Brodbelt research group is to develop innovative ways to analyze proteins and improve the determination of their structures. Mass spectrometry has become one of the best analytical tools to characterize proteins, and advances in mass spectrometry have allowed new insight into sequence variations and pivotal post-translational modifications that modulate the structure and function of proteins.  We have focused on characterizing protein structures by ultraviolet photodissociation (UVPD), a laser-based method to dissociate proteins into diagnostic molecular fingerprints that reveal sequence, both identity and location of modifications, and mutations. 

 Some of the key outcomes include:

i)       Evaluation and optimization of parameters for UVPD of intact proteins. The absorption of high energy photons causes protein cleavages that produce reproducible and informative fragment ions that can be used to identify the protein sequence. We extended UVPD for high throughput top-down proteomics for the analysis of the proteome from cells, demonstrating that UVPD offers high scoring metrics for confident localization of modifications. We found that combining UVPD data with results from other mass spectrometry methods afforded the best performance for protein analysis. Because mass spectrometry depends on forming and analyzing molecules as charged ions, we explored methods to vary charge sites and charge states of proteins and characterized the resulting fragmentation patterns. The location of positive charge sites was found to depend on the presence of salt-bridges and conformation, structural features that add stability to proteins.

ii)      Development of selective UVPD strategies. Selective targeting methods were developed based on using UV-selective chromophores in conjunction with UVPD. Derivatization of peptides to attach suitable chromophores converted non-absorbing peptides to highly chromogenic peptides that underwent efficient fragmentation. This concept was exploited to build selectivity into the analytical workflow so that only molecules of high priority interest would be analyzed even amid complex mixtures of other non-priority molecules.

iii)     Unique merits of UVPD for collaborations. Collaborative projects were pursued to translate the framework of UVPD to high impact applications with both industrial and academic partners. We showcased UVPD for analysis of unique classes of proteins (such as selenium-containing proteins) and biologically important types of modifications (such as glycosylation) as well as immunopeptide antigens from the major histocompatibility complex, a critical step in development of vaccines.  

iv)     New supplemental strategies to maximize the information content from analytical workflows.  When generating diagnostic molecular fingerprints of complex molecules, important signals may be obscured by non-relevant interferences or may lack sufficient intensity for detection.  We designed new supplemental strategies to increase the information gained from analysis of targeted molecules in complicated mixtures. We combined specific types of chemical reactions in the gas phase, such proton transfer charge reduction, with UVPD to decongest spectra and separate overlapping signals. This method allowed manipulation of charge states of proteins and fragment ions in dense regions of spectra to simplify and aid in interpretation.  In addition, highly intense but uninformative molecular species were removed from spectra to enhance detection of low intensity but vital species.   

Beyond the research mission, there was an array of broader impacts.  Education and training of future scientist leaders, including women and minorities, was emphasized throughout the duration of the project. Graduate students were trained in the use of advanced mass spectrometry, lasers, chemical reactions, sample preparation method, data analysis, optics and lasers. In addition to scientific training, students participated in professional development activities including the preparation of scientific manuscripts and presentations, engaging in collaborative interactions, the practice of lab safety, and career planning. Numerous collaborations were established with both academic and industrial partners, allowing students to benefit from projects of greater scope and providing networking opportunities. 

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2022
Modified by: Jennifer S Brodbelt
